utterances: Joe Lopez, who lost 125 pounds with the Lap-Band, says he still has an eating problem too.
Lopez says once he even had the doctor loosen his Lap-Band.
He was going on his honeymoon and wanted to indulge.
Because I went to an all-inclusive resort and I wanted to eat a little more.
So I asked my doctor to if I could get it adjusted and I gained, like 20 pounds.
And it shows.
Left to my own devices, I can gain about 20 pounds in a couple weeks.
Once back, he had it tightened and dropped the extra weight.
Such success stories have helped propel the number of bariatric surgeries performed every year - more than 200,000 annually and that number could grow higher.
Allergan, the maker of the Lap-Band, recently got FDA approval to market the device to people needing to lose as little as 50 pounds.
And the company is waiting for approval for its use in another obese group - teenagers.
Carrie Kahn, NPR News.
This is NEWS & NOTES.
I'm Ed Gordon.
On today's roundtable, the pope stresses abstinence in Africa; reverse discrimination charges at an Oregon college, and health insurance from Costco.
Joining us in our discussion today, from our New York bureau, E.R.
Shipp, columnist at the New York Daily News, and Robert George, editorial writer at the New York Post.
And George Curry joins us.
He's editor in chief of the National Newspaper Publishers Association News Service.
He comes to us from Maryland.
And thank you for mentioning it on Christmas Day.

If the government can use administrative subpoenas in health-care fraud investigations and in drug cases, then the obvious question is why can't we use them in the international terrorism investigations?
Other members of the committee say there's a very good reason.
The kinds of records sought in terror investigations are among the most sensitive.
On the Senate floor Monday, Oregon Senator Ron Wyden imagined what would happen if a local FBI official went after medical records.

The head of the local field office could issue an administrative subpoena to a hospital director and ask for all the hospital's medical records simply by claiming they were relevant to an investigation.
The patients wouldn't even know that their records had been seized.
They would be totally in the dark.

The administrative subpoena broadens a provision of the Patriot Act that has already sparked tremendous opposition, Section 215, which allows the FBI to get hold of documents needed for terror investigations upon approval by a special court.
The administrative subpoena would remove that oversight.
At a recent hearing, FBI Director Robert Mueller said having to go to court takes too much time.
If you're comparing on the one hand the use of the 215 process and the administrative subpoena process, they're night and day.
The fact of the matter is, the 215 process is somewhat burdensome.
But civil liberties groups say the burden of judicial review ensures the FBI does not go on any fishing expeditions through the records of innocent people.
Senator Ron Wyden proposed a compromise on Monday.
Under the proposal I make today, if the FBI needs information right away, right away, the FBI could notify a judge that they were going to get it, and then go get it without waiting for a response.
But that proposal was not adopted.
The committee tried to balance these new police powers by demanding more information about how administrative subpoenas are used.
The FBI will also have to report to Congress on how it uses another tool known as a mail cover, which allows agents to trace letters through the Postal Service.
But at the same time, the FBI will get more authority over the Postal Service.
Zoe Strickland, chief privacy officer for the Postal Service, is concerned about language that would take away the authority of the Postal Inspection Service to resist or limit such searches.

The inspection service are the experts around mail, so it seems appropriate that they would work hand in glove with the requesting agency, and we're not quite sure how it would work with just a `thou shalt' sort of direction.
The Senate's Patriot Act renewal still faces review before the Judiciary Committee, and the House is still holding hearings on efforts to renew key Patriot powers before they expire on December 31st.
But the Intelligence Committee's 11-to-4 vote shows there's still strong support in Congress for the Patriot Act.
Larry Abramson, NPR News, Washington.
David Price is a Democratic congressman from North Carolina, which is the home of Blackwater.
He sponsored the bill on the House that would hold contractors accountable under U.S.
law.
That bill passed in the House by a wide margin, and Price predicts it will pass in the Senate in coming days as well.
The White House opposes the bill.
I asked him what it's meant to do.

Now, the contractors for the Department of Defense are covered under this Military Extraterritorial Jurisdiction Act - we call it MEJA, but contractors for the State Department or other agencies are not.
So we want to bring everyone under the same regime of law, and then of course, the task will remain of making certain that the administration prosecutes those who deserve prosecution.
Those FBI offices that you mentioned, that's one of the reasons that the White House is very strongly opposed to your bill.
It says that having offices like you who would stipulate would really stretch the FBI too thin.
Well, it's their job to figure out what resources would be needed and then to begin to provide them and ask Congress for them.
Yes, this is - would be a new function.
We entirely understand that and intend it.
Would your bill, that would bring these contractors under U.S.
civilian law, would it apply retroactively though, would it apply, say, to the Blackwater shooting back in September?
No, it would not apply retroactively.
I think there's no way to do that.
That, however, should not let the Justice Department and the State Department off the hook in this case.
These findings that the New York Times has made public are very, very serious, and it sounds as though prosecution is warranted.
And the State Department and the Justice Department, and most particularly our new attorney general, have got to find a way to do this.
There's no question the law is deficient, and we hope to fix the law going forward.
But that can't be an excuse not to deal with this case perhaps utilizing the War Crimes Act.
And of course, the State Department has some authority under the contract to do some things.
Do you think they'll do that?
I'm certainly hopeful they'll do it.
This is serious business.

This is compromising our mission in Iraq to say nothing of the innocent lives lost and the fact that we just cannot tolerate this kind of lawless behavior on the part of American citizens wherever they are.
I'd like to have you respond to criticism from the other side, this time from Peter Singer of the Brookings Institution who spent a lot of time studying military contractors and likes your bill.
But he told a reporter, it's like we've woken up to the fact the emperor has no clothes, and now we're just putting a scarf on it.
So that isn't satisfactory.
You know, no - the best law in the world isn't going to be self-executing.
And so the administration needs to get serious about this in more ways than one.
This is not just a matter of justice in individual cases.
This is a matter of the rule of law and what this country stands for and the effectiveness of our missions.
This - the importance of this shouldn't be underestimated.
Congressman Price, thanks for talking with us today.
Thank you very much.
That's Congressman David Price, a Democrat from North Carolina.
The set represents a massive amount of work.
Nothing in recent memory -not the Neil Young archives project or the 31-disc set of Daniel Schorr Commentaries: The Dutch Years, 1940-1953 - comes close.
But this isn't merely entertainment.
The Funding Announcements Collection serves as an almost complete oral history of corporate America.
(Soundbite of CD clip)
NPR programs are supported by Bernard L.
Madoff Investment Securities LLC.
Watching over your investments so you don't have to.
And the tourism bureau of the German Democratic Republic.
Come see us and stay awhile.
The box set isn't perfect, of course.
There's inevitably some repetition over the years.
But hang in there because when you pay attention without the pesky distractions of the news and commentaries, you begin to appreciate these bits as the very bedrock of public radio.
They slip past our consciousness almost unnoticed, but they're always there in the background - an ethereal, almost magical presence connecting us to the true spirit of the endeavor.
That's critic Tom Moon.
The CD boxed set is the collected underwriting credits of NPR, volumes 1-20.
To hear and see Arthur Di Fecanti perform, go to our Web site, NPR.org.
Shakespeare might have had the Democrats in mind when he wrote in Hamlet that sorrows come not in single spies, but in battalions.
NPR Senior News Analyst Daniel Schorr.
In his address tonight, President Obama is as much concerned about the state of his party in the wake of the stunning loss of Ted Kennedys seat as he is about the state of the union.
In The Hill newspaper today, Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid says that Massachusetts may have changed the math in the congressional lineup, but we will fight on.
Fight has become a chosen word in Democratic parlance.

In his speech in Ohio last week, reacting to the loss of the Massachusetts seat, the president used the word fight or fighting a total of 22 times, and one can expect a combative president tonight embracing a disaffected electorate.
But the impact of Massachusetts is becoming evident.
Joseph Biden III has suddenly bowed out of the race for his fathers Senate seat in Delaware.
Arkansas Representative Marion Berry has announced his retirement.
And up to a dozen other House members are reportedly considering an exit strategy.
The Massachusetts setback came not singly, but after the Democrats had lost the governorships of New Jersey and Virginia.
The immediate effect was to inspire the almost-leaderless Republicans, although opinion polls indicate that disillusionment with Democrats does not add up to an embrace of Republicans.
The voters are in a plague on both your houses mood.
But its the Democrats, still formally in command of Congress, who need help if anything is to be enacted from health care reform to a freeze on domestic spending.
For the president, this represents a special challenge.
In an interview with Diane Sawyer of ABC, he said that he would rather be a really good one-term president than a mediocre two-term president.
The question is whether resurgent Republicans and even independents will allow him to be an effective president.
In these volatile times, change could come quickly.
But for now, these seem to be dark days for Democrats.
This is Daniel Schorr.
